## Fix applied: handle API response shape and guard against undefined templates

Your error comes from a response shape mismatch. Our API helpers wrap payloads under data, but the hook was trying to read templates at the top level. When success is true with no templates, data.templates was undefined, and the code tried to read its length.

I updated app/domains/campaigns/hooks/useTemplates.ts to:
- Read templates from json.data.templates
- Guard with a safe default []
- Add a small HTTP status check
- Simplify logging to avoid undefined meta fields

### Key change (excerpt)
````typescript path=app/domains/campaigns/hooks/useTemplates.ts mode=EXCERPT
const json = await response.json();
const payload = json?.data as { templates?: UnifiedTemplate[] } | undefined;
const safeTemplates: UnifiedTemplate[] = Array.isArray(payload?.templates)
 ? payload!.templates
 : [];

if (json?.success) {
 setTemplates(safeTemplates);
} else {
 setError(json?.error || "Failed to load templates");
 setTemplates([]);
}
````

## Why this fixes it
- API responses are standardized as { success, data, error, timestamp }. The hook now reads templates via json.data.templates.
- If no templates are returned, safeTemplates defaults to [] so no length-of-undefined error.

## What you should see now
- The console should log something like: “Templates loaded: 0 templates” instead of throwing.
- BasePopup and other components should continue rendering without the previous error.

## Notes / optional follow-ups
- The hook sends goal and storeId as query params, but /api/templates currently looks for type (templateType) and derives storeId from auth. This is okay for now, but we can add filtering by goal or map goal -> type if desired.
- We can add ApiResponse typing to the hook for stronger compile-time checks if you want.

## Short answer
Because the API that powers the selector doesn’t filter by goal. The hook sends goal in the URL, but /api/templates only looks at type and returns all templates (or all by type). TemplateService queries also don’t include any filter on the Template.goals column, so changing goal has no effect.

## Where this happens
- Client: useTemplates calls /api/templates?storeId=...&goal=... (goal sent)
- API: app/routes/api.templates.tsx ignores goal and only checks type/default
- DB: Template model has goals CampaignGoal[] but TemplateService methods don’t filter on it

## Minimal fix (server-side)
Add goal support in the API and service so templates are filtered by goals.

- API loader: read goal and route to goal-aware queries
````ts path=app/routes/api.templates.tsx mode=EXCERPT
import type { CampaignGoal } from "@prisma/client";

const goal = url.searchParams.get("goal") as CampaignGoal | null;

if (defaultOnly && templateType) {
 const t = await TemplateService.getDefault....findMany({
 where: { ...globalOrStoreWhere(storeId), isActive: true, goals: { has: goal } },
 orderBy: [{ priority: "desc" }, { createdAt: "desc" }],
 });
 return templates.map(parseTemplateEntity);
}

static async getTemplatesByTypeAndGoal(templateType: TemplateType, goal: CampaignGoal, storeId?: string) {
 const templates = await prisma.template.findMany({
 where: { templateType, ...globalOrStoreWhere(storeId), isActive: true, goals: { has: goal } },
 orderBy: [{ priority: "desc" }, { createdAt: "desc" }],
 });
 return templates.map(parseTemplateEntity);
}
````

## Quick workaround (client-side)
If you prefer not to touch the API yet, you can filter in the hook after fetch:
````ts path=app/domains/campaigns/hooks/useTemplates.ts mode=EXCERPT
const safeTemplates = Array.isArray(payload?.templates) ? payload.templates : [];
setTemplates(goal ? safeTemplates.filter(t => t.goals?.includes(goal)) : safeTemplates);
````

export function parseTemplateContentConfig(
 jsonValue: unknown,
 templateType?: TemplateType
): ContentConfig | BaseContentConfig {
 const schema = getTemplateContentSchema(templateType);
 try {
 if (jsonValue === null || jsonValue === undefined) {
 return {} as BaseContentConfig;
 }
 let parsed: unknown;
 if (typeof jsonValue === 'string') {
 parsed = JSON.parse(jsonValue);
 } else {
 parsed = jsonValue;
 }
 const result = schema.safeParse(parsed);
 return result.success ? result.data : {} as BaseContentConfig;
 } catch (error) {
 console.warn('Failed to parse template contentConfig:', error);
 return {} as BaseContentConfig;
 }
}
```

 templateType?: TemplateType
): ContentConfig | BaseContentConfig {
 const schema = getTemplateContentSchema(templateType);

 if (jsonValue === null || jsonValue === undefined) {
 return {} as BaseContentConfig;

 } catch (error) {

 }
}

const THEME_DEFAULTS: Record<DesignConfig["theme"], { background: string; text: string; button: string }> = {
 "professional-blue": { background: "#FFFFFF", text: "#1F2937", button: "#2563EB" },
 "vibrant-orange": { background: "#FFFFFF", text: "#1F2937", button: "#F97316" },
 "elegant-purple": { background: "#FFFFFF", text: "#111827", button: "#7C3AED" },
 "minimal-gray": { background: "#F9FAFB", text: "#111827", button: "#111827" },
};

// Automatic readable text color calculation
function pickReadableTextColor(bgHex: string): string {
 const rgb = hexToRgb(bgHex);
 if (!rgb) return "#FFFFFF";
 const yiq = (rgb.r * 299 + rgb.g * 587 + rgb.b * 114) / 1000;
 return yiq >= 128 ? "#000000" : "#FFFFFF";
}

// Typed color resolution from DesignConfig
function getDesignPreviewColors(design: DesignConfig) {
 const defaults = THEME_DEFAULTS[design.theme] ?? THEME_DEFAULTS["professional-blue"];
 const backgroundColor = design.backgroundColor ?? defaults.background;
 const textColor = design.textColor ?? defaults.text;
 const buttonColor = design.buttonColor ?? defaults.button;
 const buttonTextColor = pickReadableTextColor(buttonColor);
 return { backgroundColor, textColor, buttonColor, buttonTextColor };
}

// Typed content field extraction by templateType
function getPreviewTexts(template: Template) {
 const content = parseTemplateContentConfig(template.contentConfig, template.templateType);
 switch (template.templateType) {
 case "NEWSLETTER":
 case "EXIT_INTENT": {
 const c = content as NewsletterContent;
 return {
 title: c.headline ?? template.name,
 button: c.submitButtonText ?? c.buttonText ?? c.ctaText ?? "Select",
 description: template.description,
 };
 }
 case "SPIN_TO_WIN":
 case "SCRATCH_CARD": {
 const c = content as SpinToWinContent;
 return {
 title: c.headline ?? template.name,
 button: c.spinButtonText ?? c.buttonText ?? c.ctaText ?? "Select",
 description: template.description,
 };
 }
 case "FLASH_SALE":
 case "COUNTDOWN_TIMER": {
 const c = content as FlashSaleContent;
 return {
 title: c.headline ?? template.name,
 button: c.ctaText ?? c.buttonText ?? "Shop now",
 description: template.description,
 };
 }
 default: {
 const c = content as BaseContentConfig;
 return {
 title: c.headline ?? template.name,
 button: c.ctaText ?? c.buttonText ?? "Select",
 description: template.description,
 };
 }
 }
}

// Usage in render (no any-casts)
{templates.map((template) => {
 const texts = getPreviewTexts(template);
 const colors = getDesignPreviewColors(template.designConfig);
 
 return (
 <div className={styles.templatePreview} style={{ backgroundColor: colors.backgroundColor }}>
 <div className={styles.templatePreviewContent} style={{ color: colors.textColor }}>
 <div className={styles.templateTitle}>{texts.title}</div>
 <div className={styles.templateButton} 
 style={{ backgroundColor: colors.buttonColor, color: colors.buttonTextColor }}>

 );
})}

## 3. Key Technical Concepts

- **Template Architecture**:
 - **Template ID** (`template.id`): Unique CUID identifier for a specific template configuration instance
 - **Template Type** (`template.templateType`): Enum value representing the React component to render (e.g., `NEWSLETTER`, `FLASH_SALE`, `SPIN_TO_WIN`)
 - **Template Category** (`template.category`): High-level category string for grouping/filtering templates
 - Multiple templates can share the same `templateType` but have different `contentConfig`, `designConfig`, `targetRules`, etc.

- **Domain Template Model** (`app/domains/templates/types/template.ts`):
 - `TemplateWithConfigs` schema includes structured JSON configs: `contentConfig`, `designConfig`, `targetRules`, `discountConfig`, `fields`
 - `BaseTemplateSchema` defines core template properties
 - **Typed Content Schemas**: `NewsletterContentSchema`, `FlashSaleContentSchema`, `SpinToWinContentSchema` provide proper typing for `contentConfig` based on `templateType`
 - **Helper Function**: `parseTemplateContentConfig(jsonValue, templateType)` - Parses and validates contentConfig with proper typing based on templateType
 - **Helper Function**: `getTemplateContentSchema(templateType)` - Returns the appropriate Zod schema for a given template type

- **TemplateType Enum**: `NEWSLETTER`, `SPIN_TO_WIN`, `FLASH_SALE`, `FREE_SHIPPING`, `EXIT_INTENT`, `CART_ABANDONMENT`, `PRODUCT_UPSELL`, `SOCIAL_PROOF`, `COUNTDOWN_TIMER`, `SCRATCH_CARD`, `ANNOUNCEMENT`

- **CampaignGoal Enum**: `NEWSLETTER_SIGNUP`, `INCREASE_REVENUE`, `ENGAGEMENT`

- **Zod Schemas for Type Safety**:
 - All template configs use Zod schemas for validation
 - Content schemas vary by template type (Newsletter, FlashSale, SpinToWin, etc.)
 - Design config schema is shared across all template types
 - DesignConfig defaults: `{ theme: "professional-blue", position: "center", size: "medium", borderRadius: 8, overlayOpacity: 0.8, animation: "fade" }`
 - DiscountConfig defaults: `{ enabled: false }`

- **Content Config Types**:
 - `BaseContentConfig`: Fields shared by all templates (headline, subheadline, buttonText, successMessage, failureMessage, ctaText)
 - `NewsletterContent`: Extends base with emailPlaceholder, emailLabel, submitButtonText, nameFieldEnabled, etc.
 - `SpinToWinContent`: Extends base with spinButtonText, wheelSegments, emailRequired, etc.
 - `FlashSaleContent`: Extends base with urgencyMessage, discountPercentage, showCountdown, countdownDuration, etc.

- **Design Config**:
 - `theme`: Enum of "professional-blue", "vibrant-orange", "elegant-purple", "minimal-gray"
 - `position`: Enum of "center", "top", "bottom", "left", "right"
 - `size`: Enum of "small", "medium", "large"
 - Optional color overrides: `backgroundColor`, `textColor`, `buttonColor`
 - `borderRadius`, `overlayOpacity`, `animation`, `customCSS`

- **Theme-based Color Defaults**:
 - Each theme has default background, text, and button colors
 - Colors can be overridden in DesignConfig
 - Button text color is automatically calculated for readability using YIQ luminance formula

## 3. Key Technical Concepts

### Template System Architecture
- **Database-first approach**: Templates are seeded globally in the database via `prisma/template-data.ts`
- **Template-to-Component mapping**: `PopupManagerReact.tsx` uses a switch statement on `resolvedType` (normalized templateType) to route to the appropriate React component
- **Type normalization**: `templateType` is converted to lowercase and underscores replaced with hyphens (e.g., `SPIN_TO_WIN` → `spin-to-win`)

### Template Data Structure
Each template in the seed data contains:
- `name`: Display name
- `description`: Purpose description
- `category`: Grouping (engagement, sales, announcement)
- `templateType`: Enum value linking to React component
- `goals`: Array of CampaignGoal values (NEWSLETTER_SIGNUP, INCREASE_REVENUE, ENGAGEMENT)
- `contentConfig`: Default content values (headline, subheadline, ctaText, etc.)
- `fields`: Array of customizable field definitions
- `targetRules`: Default trigger/targeting configuration with `enhancedTriggers`
- `designConfig`: Default design settings (colors, position, size)
- `discountConfig`: Optional discount configuration
- `isDefault`: Boolean indicating system template
- `priority`: Integer for ordering
- `icon`: Emoji or icon identifier
- `conversionRate`: Performance metric (percentage as decimal)

### React Component Mapping (PopupManagerReact.tsx)
The switch statement maps normalized templateTypes to components:
- `"modal"`, `"newsletter"`, `"newsletter-elegant"`, `"newsletter-minimal"` → `ModalPopup`
- `"spin-to-win"`, `"lottery"` → `SpinToWinPopup`
- `"scratch-card"` → `ScratchCardPopup`
- `"slide-in"`, `"slide"` → `SlideInPopup`
- `"banner"` → `BannerPopup`
- Default fallback → `ModalPopup`

**Note**: Many templateTypes from the seed data are NOT explicitly handled in the switch statement, meaning they fall through to the default ModalPopup renderer.

### Type System
- **Zod schemas**: Used for validation and type inference
- **Template-specific content schemas**: `NewsletterContentSchema`, `FlashSaleContentSchema`, `SpinToWinContentSchema`
- **Generic fallback**: `BaseContentConfigSchema` for templates without specific schemas
- **Type-safe parsing**: `parseTemplateContentConfig()` function handles JSON parsing with proper typing

### Trigger System
Templates define default triggers via `targetRules.enhancedTriggers`:
- `page_load`: { enabled, delay }
- `exit_intent`: { enabled, sensitivity }
- `time_delay`: { enabled, delay }
- `scroll_depth`: { enabled, depth_percentage }
- `product_view`: { enabled, time_on_page }

- `idle_timer`: { enabled, idle_duration }

## Short answer
Yes—it's reasonable to relax or even disable @typescript-eslint/no-explicit-any in tests. Keep it strict in application code, but tests often need quick-and-dirty mocks and flexible payloads.

## Recommended approach
- App code (src): keep no-explicit-any = "error"
- Test code (tests/*, *.test.tsx?): either:
 - Set to "warn" (preferred, nudges better types without blocking), or
 - Turn it "off" if it creates friction

Example ESLint override:
````json mode=EXCERPT
{
 "overrides": [
 {
 "files": ["**/*.test.*", "tests/**/*"],
 "rules": { "@typescript-eslint/no-explicit-any": "off" }
 }
 ]
}
````

## Better-than-any options in tests
- unknown with narrowing (mirrors runtime reality)
````ts mode=EXCERPT
const payload: unknown = getFixture();
if (isCartUpdateDetail(payload)) expect(payload.total).toBeGreaterThan(0);
````

- Relaxed typing helpers
 - Partial<T>, DeepPartial<T>, Record<string, unknown>
 - satisfies for shape-checking
````ts mode=EXCERPT
const client = { get: vi.fn() } satisfies Partial<ShopifyClient>;
````

- Typed mocks in Vitest
````ts mode=EXCERPT
const fn = vi.fn<[number], string>(() => "ok");
````

## My suggestion
- Set the rule to "warn" in tests so we keep the signal but avoid blocking.
- Prefer unknown + Partial<T> + satisfies + typed vi.fn in new/edited tests.
- Use any only as a last resort, with a targeted eslint-disable-next-line when truly needed.

If you want, I can apply the ESLint override for test files (warn or off)—which do you prefer?

## 5. Problem Solving:

**Root Cause Identified:**
The validation is failing because when a template is selected, the `contentConfig` from the database template is being applied to the wizard state, but if the template's `contentConfig` in the database doesn't contain the required base fields (`headline`, `buttonText`, `successMessage`), they remain undefined. When the form is submitted, the validation schema expects these fields to be strings, not undefined.

**Flow Analysis:**
1. User selects goal → `applyGoalDefaults()` called (doesn't set content fields)
2. User selects template → `setTemplateType()` called with template's `contentDefaults`
3. Template's `contentConfig` is merged: `contentConfig: { ...state.data.contentConfig, ...templateDefaults }`
4. If template's database record has empty/incomplete `contentConfig`, required fields are missing
5. Form submission → validation fails because `headline`, `buttonText`, `successMessage` are undefined

**Key Issue:**
The templates in the database may not have default values for the required base content fields, OR the defaults are not being properly applied when the template is selected.

- **Incorrect storeId usage**: Loaders were passing `session.shop` (Shopify shop domain) to services, but services expect the internal `storeId` from `getStoreId(request)` helper

I fixed these issues in multiple route files and the user then requested to "add tests to cover this use case."

## 3. Key Technical Concepts

- **Remix Framework**: React-based framework with loaders and actions for data fetching
- **React Router v7**: Used for routing and data loading (`data()` function, `useLoaderData`, `useNavigate`)
- **A/B Testing Architecture**: "Variants as Full Campaigns" - each variant (A, B, C, D) is a complete Campaign object sharing the same experimentId
- **Campaign Types**:
 - `CampaignWithConfigs`: Campaign with all related configurations
 - `experimentId`: Links campaigns to experiments (nullable string)
 - `variantKey`: "A" | "B" | "C" | "D" (nullable)
 - `isControl`: Boolean indicating control variant
- **Experiment Types**:
 - `ExperimentWithVariants`: Experiment with associated variant campaigns
 - Contains: id, name, description, status, trafficAllocation, variants array
- **Shopify Polaris**: UI component library (Card, ResourceList, Badge, Frame, Toast, Page, etc.)
- **Services**:
 - `CampaignService.getAllCampaigns(storeId)`: Fetches all campaigns
 - `CampaignService.getCampaignById(id, storeId)`: Fetches single campaign
 - `CampaignService.createCampaign(storeId, data)`: Creates a new campaign
 - `ExperimentService.getAllExperiments(storeId)`: Fetches all experiments
 - `ExperimentService.createExperiment(storeId, data)`: Creates a new experiment
- **Authentication Helpers**:
 - `getStoreId(request)`: Resolves internal storeId from Shopify session, creates Store record if needed
 - `authenticate.admin(request)`: Returns session with shop domain
- **API Response Structure**: `{ success: boolean, data: T, error?: string, errors?: string[], timestamp: string }`
 - Campaign creation: `{ success: true, data: { campaign: {...} } }`
 - Experiment creation: `{ success: true, data: { experiment: {...} } }`
- **Testing Stack**: 
 - Vitest with @testing-library/react
 - happy-dom environment
 - vi.mock for mocking modules
 - Mock patterns: capturing callbacks from mocked components, mocking Polaris components to avoid AppProvider requirement

# Summary of Conversation

## 1. Previous Conversation

The user is working on a Shopify app called "revenue-boost" that displays popup campaigns on storefronts. The app uses a theme extension architecture where:
- A Liquid snippet (`popup-init.liquid`) is auto-loaded via app embed on all storefront pages
- The snippet loads a main JavaScript bundle (`popup-loader.bundle.js`) 
- The main bundle dynamically loads individual popup component bundles (newsletter, spin-to-win, etc.) on demand
- All bundles are built using esbuild and stored in `extensions/storefront-popup/assets/`

The user reported that the extension appears to be activated but is not loading properly on the storefront.

## 2. Current Work

I investigated the extension loading mechanism and identified a critical missing piece: there is no server route to serve the popup component bundles to the storefront. The architecture shows:

1. **Extension Structure**: The theme extension at `extensions/storefront-popup/` contains:
 - `snippets/popup-init.liquid` - Auto-loaded initialization script that sets up `window.REVENUE_BOOST_CONFIG` and loads the main bundle
 - `assets/*.bundle.js` - 12 pre-built JavaScript bundles (main loader + 11 popup types)
 - `shopify.extension.toml` - Extension configuration with UID `725cd6d8-2f2b-91cb-b1be-3983c340fe6376935e80`

2. **Component Loader Logic** (`extensions/storefront-src/core/component-loader.ts`):
 - Uses a 3-strategy approach to load components:
 - Strategy 1: Check global registry `window.RevenueBoostComponents`
 - Strategy 2: Try dynamic import (disabled in production)

 // For dark input backgrounds, use the theme's text color

 // For light backgrounds, use dark text

 };

 return {

 buttonTextColor: themeColors.ctaText || "#FFFFFF",
 inputBackgroundColor: themeColors.secondary,

 inputBorderColor: themeColors.inputBorder || themeColors.border,

- Eliminate need for JavaScript width tracking and duplicate CSS rules

**Implementation:**
1. Removed all JavaScript-based responsive logic (state, ResizeObserver, dynamic classes)
2. Added `container-type: inline-size` and `container-name: popup` to `.email-popup-container`
3. Replaced media queries with container queries: `@container popup (min-width: 768px)`
4. Removed all duplicate CSS rules for `.mobile` and `.desktop` variants
5. Kept fallback media query for max-width on container

**Result:**
- ✅ Mobile preview (< 768px container) shows vertical stacked layout
- ✅ Desktop preview (≥ 768px container) shows side-by-side layout
- ✅ Works in both preview mode and live mode
- ✅ No JavaScript overhead
- ✅ Clean, maintainable CSS
- ✅ ~40 lines of code removed

### Problem 2: Theme Color Mapping Issues

**Issue 1: Input Text Color (Gradient Theme)**
- Gradient theme uses white text (`#ffffff`) for headings on purple gradient background
- Input background is very light transparent (`rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.15)`)
- Using white text on light background = invisible/unreadable text

**Solution:**
Added smart input text color detection in `themeColorsToDesignConfig()`:
- Detects rgba transparent white backgrounds → uses dark text (`#111827`)
- Detects dark hex backgrounds (brightness < 128) → uses theme text color
- Default for light backgrounds → uses dark text (`#111827`)

**Result:**
- ✅ Gradient theme: Dark text on light transparent input background (readable!)
- ✅ Bold theme: Dark text on light transparent input background
- ✅ Glass theme: Dark text on light transparent input background
- ✅ Dark theme: Light text on dark input background
- ✅ Luxury theme: Gold text on dark input background
- ✅ Neon theme: Cyan text on dark input background

**Issue 2: Description Color**
- Mockup has specific `descColor` field for description text
- Was using `accentColor` (mapped from `primary`) for descriptions
- Semantically incorrect mapping

**Solution:**
Updated mapping to use `descColor` for `accentColor`:
```typescript
accentColor: themeColors.descColor || themeColors.primary,
```

**Result:**
- ✅ Description text now uses correct `descColor` from each theme
- ✅ Falls back to `primary` if `descColor` not defined (backward compatibility)

# Conversation Summary

## 1. Previous Conversation

The user reported an issue where clicking the "Edit" button on an experiment in the campaign list was causing navigation problems - the page would navigate to the edit page and then quickly redirect to the overview page. The root cause was identified as navigation logic being called during the render phase instead of in `useEffect` hooks, which React doesn't allow.

After fixing the initial navigation warnings, the user requested implementation of three distinct navigation behaviors for experiments in the CampaignList component:

1. **Clicking the experiment row itself** - Should navigate to `/app/experiments/{experimentId}` (the read-only overview/detail page)
2. **Clicking the "Edit" button on the experiment row** - Should navigate to `/app/experiments/{experimentId}/edit` (the editable form)
3. **Individual variant edit buttons** - Add "Edit" buttons for each variant in the expanded variant list that navigate to `/app/experiments/{experimentId}/edit` with the specific variant pre-selected via query parameter (e.g., `/app/experiments/{experimentId}/edit?variant=B`)

All three navigation behaviors were implemented, and comprehensive tests were created. However, a new issue emerged where clicking the dropdown arrow was redirecting to the overview page, which was fixed by adding `stopPropagation()` to the arrow button.

After implementing all the navigation behaviors and creating tests, the user reported that the Edit and Edit Variant buttons still don't display the form.

## 2. Current Work

The investigation revealed that when clicking the "Edit" or "Edit Variant" buttons, the navigation handler was being called correctly (as evidenced by the console log `[Campaign Index] handleExperimentEdit called with experimentId: cmhvyzpyg0001ur52sztaey9e variantKey: undefined`), but there were no logs from the Experiment Edit Loader or the Experiment Edit Page component. This indicated that the route wasn't being loaded at all.

Additionally, there was a Polaris warning: `<ResourceList /> renderItem function should return a <ResourceItem />`, which suggested that the CampaignList component's renderItem function was returning something other than a ResourceItem directly.

Two critical issues were identified and fixed:

1. **Polaris ResourceList Issue**: The renderItem function was wrapping the ResourceItem in a `<Box>` component and including the expanded variants section inside that Box. Polaris ResourceList expects renderItem to return ONLY a ResourceItem, not a Box containing a ResourceItem. This was fixed by:
 - Removing the outer `<Box>` wrapper
 - Moving the expanded variants section inside the ResourceItem instead of after it

2. **React Router File Naming Issue**: The experiment edit route was named `app.experiments.$experimentId.edit.tsx`, but the campaign edit route was named `app.campaigns.$campaignId_.edit.tsx` with an underscore before `.edit`. In React Router 7 file-based routing, the underscore is significant for route matching. The file was renamed from `app.experiments.$experimentId.edit.tsx` to `app.experiments.$experimentId_.edit.tsx` to match the correct pattern.

The user then reminded to update the tests to reflect these changes.

## 3. Key Technical Concepts

- **React Router 7 file-based routing**: Routes are defined by file names in the `app/routes/` directory
- **React Router naming conventions**: The underscore (`_`) before `.edit` in route file names (e.g., `app.experiments.$experimentId_.edit.tsx`) is required for proper route matching
- **useEffect hooks**: Required for side effects like navigation to prevent React warnings
- **Event propagation**: Using `stopPropagation()` to prevent parent click handlers from firing
- **Shopify Polaris ResourceList**: The `renderItem` function must return a `<ResourceItem>` directly, not wrapped in other components
- **A/B Testing Architecture**: Variants as full Campaign objects sharing the same experimentId
- **Variant selection**: Using `currentVariantKey` prop in CampaignFormWithABTesting to pre-select variants
- **Component props pattern**: Callback props for navigation (`onExperimentSelect`, `onExperimentEdit`, `onCampaignEdit`)
- **Query parameters**: Using URL search params to pass variant selection state
- **Testing with @testing-library/user-event**: Simulating user interactions in tests
- **Vitest**: Testing framework used for unit tests

## 5. Problem Solving

**Problem 1: React navigation warnings**
- **Cause**: Calling `navigate()` during component render phase
- **Solution**: Wrapped all `navigate()` calls in `useEffect` hooks with proper dependencies

**Problem 2: Inefficient navigation flow for experiments**
- **Cause**: Edit button called `onCampaignEdit(variantId)` which navigated to campaign edit page, then redirected to experiment edit
- **Solution**: Created separate `onExperimentEdit` handler that navigates directly to `/app/experiments/{experimentId}/edit`

**Problem 3: Row click and button click both firing**
- **Cause**: Button click events bubbling up to parent ResourceItem
- **Solution**: Added `e?.stopPropagation?.()` to button click handlers

**Problem 4: Dropdown arrow click redirecting to overview page**
- **Cause**: Arrow button click events bubbling up to parent ResourceItem
- **Solution**: Added `e?.stopPropagation?.()` to the expand/collapse arrow button (line 527 in CampaignList.tsx)

**Problem 5: Polaris ResourceList warning and navigation not working**
- **Cause**: renderItem function was returning a `<Box>` wrapping a `<ResourceItem>` instead of returning the ResourceItem directly
- **Solution**: Removed the outer Box wrapper and moved expanded variants inside the ResourceItem

**Problem 6: Experiment edit route not loading**
- **Cause**: Route file was named `app.experiments.$experimentId.edit.tsx` without the underscore before `.edit`, which doesn't match React Router 7's file-based routing convention
- **Solution**: Renamed file to `app.experiments.$experimentId_.edit.tsx` to match the pattern used by campaign edit route

You're absolutely right! I found the issue. **Capping is currently NOT done by experiment key** - it's being done by individual campaign ID, which is incorrect for A/B tests.

## The Problem

Looking at the frequency capping implementation in `app/domains/targeting/services/frequency-cap.server.ts`:

````typescript path=app/domains/targeting/services/frequency-cap.server.ts mode=EXCERPT
const campaignId = campaign.id;
const identifier = context.visitorId || context.sessionId || 'anonymous';
const now = Date.now();

// Check cooldown first
const cooldownResult = await this.checkCooldown(identifier, campaignId, now);
````

And the Redis keys are built using the campaign ID:

````typescript path=app/domains/targeting/services/frequency-cap.server.ts mode=EXCERPT
const baseKey = `${REDIS_PREFIXES.FREQUENCY_CAP}:${identifier}:${campaignId}`;
````

## What This Means

When you have an A/B test with variants A and B:
- Variant A (campaign ID: `abc123`) has its own frequency cap counter
- Variant B (campaign ID: `def456`) has a **separate** frequency cap counter
- If a user sees variant A 3 times, then somehow sees variant B, variant B starts counting from 0

## What Should Happen

All variants of the same experiment should **share the same frequency cap**. If you set "max 3 displays per day" for an experiment, the user should see at most 3 displays total across ALL variants, not 3 per variant.

## The Fix

The service should use `experimentId` when available, falling back to `campaignId` for non-experiment campaigns:

```typescript
const trackingKey = campaign.experimentId || campaign.id;
```

Would you like me to fix this?

# Conversation Summary

## 1. Previous Conversation:
The user reported a JavaScript error occurring in their Revenue Boost Shopify app's storefront extension. The error message was: `Uncaught (in promise) TypeError: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading '__H')` appearing in `newsletter.bundle.js`. This error is related to Preact hooks not being properly accessible, suggesting an issue with how the bundles are sharing the Preact runtime.

## 2. Current Work:
I was investigating a Preact hooks error in the storefront extension bundles. The investigation revealed:

- The project uses a **dual-bundle architecture** with Preact for storefront extensions:
 - Main bundle (`popup-loader.bundle.js`) - exposes Preact globally via `window.RevenueBoostPreact`
 - Individual popup bundles (e.g., `newsletter.bundle.js`) - should use the global Preact instance

- The build system uses **esbuild** with custom plugins to:
 - Alias React to Preact in the main bundle
 - Externalize Preact imports in popup bundles to use `window.RevenueBoostPreact`

- The error `Cannot read properties of undefined (reading '__H')` indicates that Preact hooks are being called but the component context is undefined, typically caused by:
 - Multiple Preact instances running simultaneously
 - Hooks being called outside of component context

- I verified that:
 - `popup-loader.bundle.js` correctly exposes `window.RevenueBoostPreact.hooks` with useState, useEffect, useCallback, useRef, useMemo
 - `newsletter.bundle.js` correctly references `window.RevenueBoostPreact.hooks`
 - The `NewsletterPopup` component imports from `'react'` which gets aliased/externalized during build

## 3. Key Technical Concepts:
- **Preact** - 3KB React alternative used for bundle size optimization
- **Lazy Loading Architecture** - Main bundle loads first, popup bundles load on-demand
- **Global Registry Pattern** - `window.RevenueBoostPreact` exposes Preact runtime globally
- **esbuild** - Build tool with custom plugins for aliasing and externalizing
- **IIFE (Immediately Invoked Function Expression)** - Bundle format for Shopify compatibility
- **Preact Hooks** - `__H` is Preact's internal hooks state property
- **Component Context (`__c`)** - Preact's internal component instance reference
- **Build Script** - `scripts/build-storefront.js` handles dual-bundle compilation
- **Shopify Theme App Extension** - Storefront extension architecture

static filterByVariantAssignment(
 campaigns: CampaignWithConfigs[],
 context: StorefrontContext
): CampaignWithConfigs[] {
 // Groups campaigns by experimentId
 const experimentGroups = new Map<string, CampaignWithConfigs[]>();
 const standaloneCampaigns: CampaignWithConfigs[] = [];
 
 campaigns.forEach(campaign => {
 if (campaign.experimentId) {
 const existing = experimentGroups.get(campaign.experimentId) || [];
 existing.push(campaign);
 experimentGroups.set(campaign.experimentId, existing);
 } else {
 standaloneCampaigns.push(campaign);
 }
 });
 
 // For each experiment, select ONE variant based on visitor ID
 const selectedVariants: CampaignWithConfigs[] = [];
 
 experimentGroups.forEach((variants, experimentId) => {
 const visitorId = context.visitorId || context.sessionId || 'anonymous';
 const hash = this.hashString(visitorId + experimentId);
 const selectedIndex = hash % variants.length;
 const selected = variants[selectedIndex];
 
 selectedVariants.push(selected);
 });
 
 return [...standaloneCampaigns, ...selectedVariants];
}
```

function ensureDiscountCode(discountConfig?: DiscountConfig): DiscountConfig | undefined {
 if (!discountConfig || !discountConfig.enabled) {
 return discountConfig;
 }

 // If code already exists, return as-is
 if (discountConfig.code) {
 return discountConfig;
 }

 // Auto-generate code if enabled but missing
 const type = (discountConfig.type || discountConfig.valueType?.toLowerCase()) as "percentage" | "fixed_amount" | "free_shipping";
 const value = discountConfig.value || 10;
 const prefix = discountConfig.prefix || "WELCOME";
 const expiryDays = discountConfig.expiryDays || 30;

 const generated = generateDiscountCode({
 type,
 value,
 prefix,
 expiresInDays: expiryDays,
 usageLimit: discountConfig.usageLimit,
 });

 return {

 code: generated.code,
 };
}

 headers: {

 variables: options?.variables,

 const assetPath = params["*"] || "";

 // Validate asset path against whitelist
 const isAllowed = ALLOWED_ASSET_PATHS.some((pattern) => pattern.test(assetPath));
 if (!isAllowed) {
 console.error(`[Assets] Rejected (not in whitelist): ${assetPath}`);
 return data({ error: "Asset not allowed" }, { status: 403 });
 }
 
 // Resolve absolute path
 const absPath = resolve(join(PUBLIC_DIR, assetPath));
 
 // Security: prevent path traversal
 if (!absPath.startsWith(PUBLIC_DIR)) {
 console.error(`[Assets] Path traversal attempt: ${absPath}`);
 return data({ error: "Invalid path" }, { status: 400 });
 }
 
 // Stream the file with proper headers
 const stream = createReadStream(absPath);
 return new Response(stream as unknown as ReadableStream, {
